\section{ML}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:ml}}
\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] \DUrole{defi}{Machine learning} ã€‚is the field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.â€ â€” Arthur Samuel (1959)
\item[] â€œA computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to  some class of tasks T and performance measure P, if its performance at  tasks in T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.â€ â€” Tom  Mitchell (1998)
\end{DUlineblock}


\subsection{åˆ†ç±»}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:id1}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{defi}{Supervised learning} ã€‚learning \(x \xRightarrow{P(y|x)} y\) with labelsï½œtargets.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{è­¦å‘Š:}{ç”Ÿæˆæ¨¡å‹ \& åˆ¤åˆ«æ¨¡å‹ \protect\(\in\protect\) Supervised learning}
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{\DUrole{defi}{ç”Ÿæˆæ¨¡å‹} å­¦ä¹ å¾—åˆ° \sphinxstylestrong{è”åˆæ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒ} \(P(x,y)\) ç„¶åæ±‚æ¡ä»¶æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚ä»¥ ç»Ÿè®¡å­¦ \& bayes ä¸ºç†è®ºåŸºç¡€ã€‚}\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
æœ´ç´ è´å¶æ–¯ï¼Œæ··åˆé«˜æ–¯æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œéšé©¬å°”å¯å¤«æ¨¡å‹
\end{quote}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{\DUrole{defi}{åˆ¤åˆ«æ¨¡å‹} å­¦ä¹ å¾—åˆ° \sphinxstylestrong{æ¡ä»¶æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒ} \(P(y|x)\)}\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
SVMï¼Œå†³ç­–æ ‘ã€‚LRï¼Œã€‚
\end{quote}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{defi}{Unsupervised learning} ã€‚learning \(P(x)\) without labels.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{defi}{clustering èšç±»}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
representation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
self\sphinxhyphen{}supervised

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
generative models/AIGC

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  \& æ— ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  ç•Œé™æ˜¯æ¨¡ç³Šçš„ã€‚}

\sphinxAtStartPar
å› ä¸ºæ²¡æœ‰å®¢è§‚çš„åˆ¤æ–­æ¥åŒºåˆ†ç›‘ç£è€…æä¾›çš„å€¼ \sphinxstylestrong{æ˜¯ featureï½œtarget}ã€‚é€šä¿—åœ°è¯´ï¼Œæ— ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ çš„å¤§å¤šæ•°å°è¯•æ˜¯æŒ‡ä»ä¸éœ€è¦äººä¸ºæ³¨é‡Šçš„æ ·æœ¬çš„åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­æŠ½å–ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚
\begin{quote}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] \(p(x)=\prod\limits_{i=1}^np(x_i|x_1,\dots,x_{i-1})\) æ— ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  \(p(x)\) å¯è¢«åˆ†è§£æˆ n ä¸ªç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ é—®é¢˜ã€‚
\item[] \(p(y|x)=\cfrac{p(x,y)}{\sum\limits_{y'}p(xy')}\) æœ‰ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  \(p(y|x)\) ç”¨æ— ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ çš„æ³•å­å…ˆå­¦ä¹ è”åˆåˆ†å¸ƒã€‚
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{quote}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] \DUrole{defi}{Semi\sphinxhyphen{}supervised learning åŠç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ } ã€‚ä¸€äº›æ ·æœ¬æœ‰ï¼Œä¸€äº›æ ·æœ¬æ²¡æœ‰ã€‚
\item[] \DUrole{defi}{Reinforcement learning å¼ºåŒ–å­¦ä¹ } ã€‚machine takes an action; teacher provides rewards
\end{DUlineblock}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
control

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
games

\end{itemize}

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.3]{{reinforcementL_1}.png}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] \DUrole{defi}{Semi\sphinxhyphen{}supervised / active learning}
\end{DUlineblock}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Evaluation  words
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Representation}: how to encode the raw data?
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Generalization}: how well can we do on unseen data?
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Interpretation}: how to explain the findings?
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Complexity}: how much time and space?
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Efficiency}: how many samples?
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Privacy}: how to respect data privacy?
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Robustness}: how to degrade gracefully under (malicious) error?
\end{DUlineblock}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{defi}{Big data} is a collection of data sets so large and  complex that it becomes difficult to process using on\sphinxhyphen{}  hand database management tools or traditional data  processing applications.

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Characteristics of Big Data:} \sphinxstylestrong{4V}
\item[] Volume
\item[] Velocity
\item[] Variaty
\item[] Veracity
\end{DUlineblock}

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.4]{{BigData_1}.png}

\item[] å…³äºåˆ†ç±»

\section{identifiability of model æ¨¡å‹çš„å¯è¯†åˆ«æ€§}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:identifiability-of-model}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.analyticsvidhya.com/blog/2021/05/statistical-modelling-and-identifiability-of-parameters/}{Statistical Modelling and Identifiability of Parameters}

\sphinxAtStartPar
å‚æ•°çš„ \DUrole{defi}{å¯è¯†åˆ«æ€§ identifiability} ä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬èƒ½å¤Ÿè·å¾—è¯¥å‚æ•°å€¼çš„ç²¾ç¡®ä¼°è®¡å€¼ã€‚åœ¨æ²¡æœ‰å¯è¯†åˆ«æ€§çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå³ä½¿æœ‰æ— é™æ¬¡è§‚æµ‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿæ— æ³•ä¼°è®¡å‚æ•°Î¸çš„çœŸå®å€¼ã€‚
\begin{quote}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Xï½N(a+b, Ïƒ) is not identifiable
\item[] Xï½N(Î¼, Ïƒ) is identifiable
\item[] æ¯ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„ Î¼ éƒ½æŒ‡å‘ä¸€ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„æœŸæœ›ï¼ŒæŒ‡å‘ä¸åŒçš„æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒï¼ŒåŒæ ·åœ°æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ‹¥æœ‰ä¸åŒæœŸæœ›çš„æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒéƒ½èƒ½å”¯ä¸€æ±‚å‡ºä¸€ä¸ª Î¼ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯å¯¹ä¸åŒçš„ a å’Œ b æ¥è¯´ï¼Œa+b ä¹Ÿè®¸æ˜¯ç›¸åŒçš„ï¼Œæ„å‘³ç€ä¸€ä¸ªæ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒå¹¶ä¸èƒ½å”¯ä¸€æ¨æ–­å‡º (a, b, Ïƒ)çš„å€¼ã€‚ï¼ˆe.g. (1, 1, Ïƒ) = (0, 2, Ïƒ)
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{quote}


\section{DNN}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:dnn}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{why it is difficult for neural networks to be deep before 2010s.}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
No enough computation resources,

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
No enough training data,

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Gradient vanish problem and no advanced optimization techniques

\end{enumerate}
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{condition}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:condition}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{Product Rule, Chain Rule and Bayesâ€™ Rule?}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Product Rule: P(y)P(x|y)=P(x,y)
\item[] Chain Rule: P(A1A2A3â€¦An)= P(A1|A2A3â€¦An) P(A2|A3A4â€¦An)â€¦ P(An\sphinxhyphen{}1| An) P(An)
\item[] Bayesâ€™ Rule: \(P(F|E)=\cfrac{P(E|F)P(F)}{P(E|F)P(F)+ P(E|\neg F)P(\neg F)}\)
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{quote}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] â“Suppose 1 in 1000 persons has a certain disease. We have two test methods:
\item[] 1ï¸âƒ£  detect the disease (produce positive results) in 99\% of the diseased persons and in 5\% of the healthy persons (false alarm).
\item[] 2ï¸âƒ£ : detect the disease (produce positive results) in 90\% of the diseased persons and in 1\% of the healthy persons (false alarm). Which test method is better? Give the reason.
\item[] ğŸ’¡
D:=\{Diseased person\}; H=\{Healthy Persons\}, +I =\{Persons with positive results with Test method I\}, +II =\{Persons with positive results with Test method II \}
\item[] \(P(D)=0.001,\\ P(+I|D)=0.99, P(+I|H)=0.05,\\ P(+II|D)=0.90, P(+II|H)=0.01\)
\item[] We compute the probability of a diseased person that can be detect by Test method I or Test method II, repectively, which is|
\item[] \(P(D|+I)= \cfrac{P(+I|D)P(D)}{P(+I|D) P(D)+ P(+I|H) P(H)}=\frac{0.99\times 0.001}{0.99\times0.001+0.05\times0.999}=0.0194\)
\item[] \(P(D|+II)= \cfrac{P(+II|D)P(D)}{P(+II|D) P(D)+ P(+II|H) P(H)}=\frac{0.90\times 0.001}{0.90\times0.001+0.01\times0.999}=0.0826\)
\item[] \(P(D|+ I)< P(D|+ II)\) It means if a person has the disease, it has more chance of being detected by Test Method II. So Test method II is better.
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{quote}


\section{search}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:search}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{A search algorithm is admissible if it is guaranteed to find a minimal path to a solution whenever such a path exists.}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{Q4. the motivations of employing heuristics in solving AI problems?}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A problem may not have an exact solution because of ambiguities in problem statement or available data

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A problem may have an exact solution, but the computational cost (time and space) of finding it may be prohibitive.

\end{enumerate}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{informed search methodâ€}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Hill\sphinxhyphen{}climbing search; A* algorithm; Best\sphinxhyphen{}first.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\subsection{BNN, Bayesian Belief networkd}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:bnn-bayesian-belief-networkd}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Bayesian Belief Net consists of a graph and some local conditional probabilities.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{notes}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Serial connection:      \(P(AVB)=P(B|V)P(V|A)P(A)\)
\item[] Diverging Connection:   \(P(AVB)=P(B|V)P(A|V)P(V)\)
\item[] Converging Connection: \(P(AVB)=P(V|AB)P(A)P(B)\)
\item[] Modus Ponens rule \(\cfrac{a,a\implies b}{b}\)
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{quote}

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.3]{{BNN_1}.png}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] \(P(ABC)=P(AB)P(C)=.6*.8*.7=.336\)
\item[] \(P(A)=.6*.8+.4*.2=.56\)
\item[] \(P(AC)=P(A)P(C)=.56*.7=.392\)
\item[] \(P(D|B)=P(D|BC)P(C)+(PD|B\neg C)P(\neg C)=.8*.7+.2*.3=.62\)
\item[] \(P(D|\neg B)=P(D|\neg BC)P(C)+(PD|\neg B\neg C)P(\neg C)=.1*.7+.1*.3=.1\)
\item[] \(P(B|D)=\cfrac{P(BD)}{P(D)}=\cfrac{P(D|B)P(B)}{P(D|B)P(B)+P(D|\neg B)P(\neg B)}=\cfrac{.62*.8}{.62*.8+.1*.2}=.9612\)
\item[] \(P(B|\neg D)=\cfrac{P(B\neg D)}{P(\neg D)}=\cfrac{P(\neg D|B)P(B)}{1-P(D)}=\cfrac{(1-P(D|B))P(B)}{1-P(D)}=.6281\)
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{quote}


\subsection{Breadth\sphinxhyphen{}firth search}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:breadth-firth-search}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{danger}{å±é™©:}{If the search space contains very deep branches without solution, breadth\sphinxhyphen{}first search will be a better choice than depth\sphinxhyphen{}first search.  Tâ€}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] æœç´¢ç©ºé—´åŒ…å«éå¸¸æ·±çš„åˆ†æ”¯ \(\neq\) ç›®æ ‡åœ¨å¾ˆæ·±çš„åˆ†æ”¯é‡Œã€‚
\item[] contains very deep branches without solution è¿™ä¸ªæ·±çš„æ”¯æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰è§£ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè§£åœ¨æµ…å±‚çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹é‡Œ \(\implies\) BFS better
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{breadth\sphinxhyphen{}first search}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{defi}{storage cost}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
branch factor \(b\)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
storage cost \(s\) bytes/node

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
search speed \(v\) nodes/second

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
goal depth \(d\)

\end{itemize}
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\sum_{i=0}^db^i\times s\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{notes}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] â“ For a searching tree, assume that the branch factor is b=10, the storage cost is 1000 bytes/node and the searching speed is 10,000 nodes/second. With breadth\sphinxhyphen{}first search, what is the required storage space at depth 3?
\item[] ğŸ’¡ At depth 3, the number of created nodes is 1+10+100+1000=111,1, and thus the storage space is 111,1ï‚´1000=11,11K bytes.
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{defi}{time complxity}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
branch factor \(b\)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
goal depth \(d\)

\end{itemize}
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}b^{d+1}\end{split}
\end{equation*}\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{ç¦»æ•£}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:id12}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{Why in some cases we need to use First Order Logic (FOL) rather than Propositional Logic (PL)?â€}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Propositional logic (PL) is too â€œcoarseâ€ to easily describe properties of objects.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
First order logic (FOL) is to extend the expressiveness of PL.

\end{enumerate}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{notes}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Forward chaining in first order logic is a data\sphinxhyphen{}driven algorithm.
\item[] Backwards chaining in first order logic is a goal\sphinxhyphen{}driven algorithm.
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{å¤‡æ³¨:}{\protect\(\forall\protect\) \& \protect\(\exists\protect\)}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(\forall x\forall y=\forall y\forall x\)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(\exists x, y = \neg \forall x\neg y\)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(\exists x\forall y\neq \forall y \exists x\)

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Satisfiable: A sentence is satisfiable if there is some interpretation for which it is true.
\item[] Unsatisfiable: A sentence is unsatisfiable if there is no interpretation for which it is true.
\item[] Valid: A sentence is valid if it is true for every interpretation.
\end{DUlineblock}
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Compute the loss of eight\sphinxhyphen{}puzzle

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.4]{{image}.png}


\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart

\section{kmeans}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:kmeans}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{danger}{å±é™©:}{Manhattan distance is <u>usually</u> larger than Euclidean distance. \(\pmb{\checkmark}\)ï¸}

\sphinxAtStartPar
å½“å­˜åœ¨ä¸‰è§’å½¢å½¢çŠ¶ï¼Œæ–œè¾¹æ¯”ç›´è§’è¾¹åŠ å’Œè¦å°
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{parameter tuning}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:parameter-tuning}}

\subsection{Guess}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:guess}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.4]{{paramT_1}.png}


\subsubsection{Grid Search}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:grid-search}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
specify a \sphinxstylestrong{list} of possible hyperparameter values éœ€è¦äººä¸ºè®¾å®šè¶…å‚æ•°çš„èŒƒå›´

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Grid Search} will train models with every possible combination of the provided hyperparameter values and assess the performance of each trained model using a specified metric (e.g., the accuracy of predictions on a test data set). \sphinxstylestrong{Grid Search} å°±ä¼šç”¨è®¾å®šåŒºé—´å†…çš„**å„ç§ç»„åˆ**è¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒå¹¶æ ¹æ®äººä¸ºæŒ‡å®šçš„metricè¿›è¡Œassess

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Limitationï¼š}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
äº‹å…ˆå¾ˆéš¾çŸ¥é“æœ€ä¼˜æ˜¯åœ¨å“ªé‡Œï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ˜¯å¦æ‰¾åˆ°æœ€ä¼˜å¾ˆä¾èµ–äººä¸ºé€‰æ‹©çš„èŒƒå›´ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”åªæ˜¯è¿›è¡ŒèŒƒå›´å†…çš„compareï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ç¡®å®šæ˜¯å¦å…¨å±€æœ€å°

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
å®¹æ˜“loss controlï¼Œå¦‚æœæ˜¯2ä¸ªhyper\sphinxhyphen{}parameterï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªæœ‰3ä¸ªå¤‡é€‰éƒ½è¦è®­ç»ƒ \(3^2\) ä¸ªmodel

\subsubsection{Random Search}
\label{\detokenize{AI/main:random-search}}
\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] \sphinxstylestrong{Idea} \DUrole{defi}{Monte Carlo methodï¼Œè’™ç‰¹å¡æ´›æ³•ï¼Œç»Ÿè®¡æ¨¡æ‹Ÿæ³•}
\item[] æ‰€æ±‚è§£é—®é¢˜å¯ä»¥è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºæŸç§éšæœºåˆ†å¸ƒçš„ç‰¹å¾æ•°ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚éšæœºäº‹ä»¶å‡ºç°çš„æ¦‚ç‡ï¼Œæˆ–è€…éšæœºå˜é‡çš„æœŸæœ›å€¼ã€‚é€šè¿‡éšæœºæŠ½æ ·çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä»¥éšæœºäº‹ä»¶å‡ºç°çš„é¢‘ç‡ä¼°è®¡å…¶æ¦‚ç‡ï¼Œæˆ–è€…ä»¥æŠ½æ ·çš„æ•°å­—ç‰¹å¾ä¼°ç®—éšæœºå˜é‡çš„æ•°å­—ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œå¹¶å°†å…¶ä½œä¸ºé—®é¢˜çš„è§£ã€‚è¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•å¤šç”¨äºæ±‚è§£å¤æ‚çš„å¤šç»´ç§¯åˆ†é—®é¢˜ã€‚
\end{DUlineblock}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Loop: 1. Random guess 2. Check and compare 3. Update.}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
provide statistical \sphinxstylestrong{distributions} of hyperparameter values äººä¸ºè®¾å®šè¶…å‚æ•°çš„åˆ†å¸ƒ

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Random Search} \sphinxstylestrong{randomly} \sphinxstylestrong{samples} hyperparameter values from the defined distributions and then tests them by generating a model. \sphinxstylestrong{Random Search} å°±ä¼šåœ¨è®¾å®šåˆ†å¸ƒå†…**éšæœºsample**è¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒå¹¶æ ¹æ®äººä¸ºæŒ‡å®šçš„metricè¿›è¡Œassess

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Advantageï¼š}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
éšæœºæœç´¢æœ‰æ•ˆåœ°æœç´¢äº†æ¯”ç½‘æ ¼æœç´¢æ›´å¤§çš„é…ç½®ç©ºé—´ã€‚å› ä¸ºæ˜¯éšæœºå–æ ·

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
æ‰¾åˆ°è¿™äº›æ˜¾æ€§è¶…å‚æ•°çš„æœ€ä½³å€¼å°†æ¯”è·å¾—æ‰€æœ‰è¶…å‚æ•°çš„æœ€ä½³ç»„åˆæ›´æœ‰æ€§ä»·æ¯”

\item {}
